title: Nvidia’s Stock Is Sinking as Doubts About Its AI Dominance Grow
summary: Shares of the chipmaker fell 2.6% on Tuesday following a report suggesting that Alphabet Inc.’s AI processors are gaining ground.  The stock is down 14% since the start of this month, erasing more than $700 billion in market value, as investors grow increasingly fearful of a bubble in AI spending as well as Nvidia’s circular investments in startups like OpenAI that are also customers.  “Nvidia’s valuation was really based on the idea that it would maintain its market share,” said Adam Sarhan, chief executive officer of 50 Park Investments.

raw.headline: Nvidia’s Stock Is Sinking as Doubts About Its AI Dominance Grow
raw.summary: Shares of the chipmaker fell 2.6% on Tuesday following a report suggesting that Alphabet Inc.’s AI processors are gaining ground.  The stock is down 14% since the start of this month, erasing more than $700 billion in market value, as investors grow increasingly fearful of a bubble in AI spending as well as Nvidia’s circular investments in startups like OpenAI that are also customers.  “Nvidia’s valuation was really based on the idea that it would maintain its market share,” said Adam Sarhan, chief executive officer of 50 Park Investments.

title: HP Inc. Has a Memory Problem. Financial Forecasts Take a Hit.
summary: The rise of artificial intelligence is turning out to be a problem for HP Inc. on two fronts.  HP Inc.  CEO said skyrocketing prices for memory chips will be a “fairly significant” drag on its results for the current fiscal year as the company issued financial guidance that fell short of what analysts had expected.  While results for the computer company’s fiscal fourth quarter exceeded forecasts, management said it expects fiscal first-quarter adjusted earnings to be between 73 cents and 81 cents a share.

raw.headline: HP Inc. Has a Memory Problem. Financial Forecasts Take a Hit.
raw.summary: The rise of artificial intelligence is turning out to be a problem for HP Inc. on two fronts.  HP Inc.  CEO said skyrocketing prices for memory chips will be a “fairly significant” drag on its results for the current fiscal year as the company issued financial guidance that fell short of what analysts had expected.  While results for the computer company’s fiscal fourth quarter exceeded forecasts, management said it expects fiscal first-quarter adjusted earnings to be between 73 cents and 81 cents a share.
